HDG.BC.content: [in atomic age, in atomic physics] what is “unforeseeable (Unvorhersehbare),” can’t be calculated/computed in advance, shows itself as something new, can’t be explained by something else—lacks a cause (atomic physics, w/ its invalidation of law of causality, refutes Kant, all previous philosophy [?]) > what is “uncaused,” [acc. atomic physics]: “spontaneous,” free
HDG.BC.linkedContent: [in atomic age, in atomic physics] what is “unforeseeable (Unvorhersehbare),” can’t be calculated/computed in advance, shows itself as something new, can’t be explained by something else—lacks a cause (atomic physics, w/ its invalidation of law of causality, refutes Kant, all previous philosophy [?]) > what is “uncaused,” [acc. atomic physics]: “spontaneous,” free

HDG.BT.content: “in taking over Descartes’ ontological position Kant made an essential omission: he failed to provide an ontology of Dasein”: the meaning of the Being of the ‘sum’
HDG.BT.linkedContent: “in taking over Descartes’ ontological position Kant made an essential omission: he failed to provide an ontology of Dasein”: the meaning of the Being of the ‘sum’

HDG.IWM.content: as long as man understands himself as rational animal, metaphysics belongs (as Kant says) to nature of man
HDG.IWM.linkedContent: as long as man understands himself as rational animal, metaphysics belongs (as Kant says) to nature of man

HDG.FS.content: no system strictly speaking in Kant, Kant speaks of unconditioned necessity, which humans require, as abyss, eternity itself in its terrible sublimity > God, for Kant, appears as abyss, “The Impossibility of Cosmological Proof of the Existence of God” = system’s impossibility
HDG.FS.linkedContent: no system strictly speaking in Kant, Kant speaks of unconditioned necessity, which humans require, as abyss, eternity itself in its terrible sublimity > God, for Kant, appears as abyss, “The Impossibility of Cosmological Proof of the Existence of God” = system’s impossibility

HDG.FS.content: for Kant, ground of everything, only idea (opposed to intuition/concept) of speculative reason, ungrounded, abyssal > Kant witnessed with horror what began to take place w/ Fichte: Fichte & Hegel look for ground where for Kant there’s only abyss
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Kant, ground of everything, only idea (opposed to intuition/concept) of speculative reason, ungrounded, abyssal > Kant witnessed with horror what began to take place w/ Fichte: Fichte & Hegel look for ground where for Kant there’s only abyss

HDG.FS.content: Kant emphasizes finitude/powerlessness of speculative reason > Hegel makes it instrument of philosophical activity, speculation becomes autonomous, unveils power impossible for Kant
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Kant emphasizes finitude/powerlessness of speculative reason > Hegel makes it instrument of philosophical activity, speculation becomes autonomous, unveils power impossible for Kant

HDG.FS.content: for Kant, power of conjoining withdraws before the Understanding, unity hasn’t disappeared but remains in background > over-interpreting, Reason as faculty of unity, perceiving of Being, withdraws behind Understanding (for Kant): ontological difference is at stake (im Spiel ist) > understanding can’t grasp/determine absolute synthesis
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Kant, power of conjoining withdraws before the Understanding, unity hasn’t disappeared but remains in background > over-interpreting, Reason as faculty of unity, perceiving of Being, withdraws behind Understanding (for Kant): ontological difference is at stake (im Spiel ist) > understanding can’t grasp/determine absolute synthesis

HDG.FS.content: Kant’s Vorstellung (representation): 1) particular representation (intuition), this book 2) representation in general, the book as such (object as object)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Kant’s Vorstellung (representation): 1) particular representation (intuition), this book 2) representation in general, the book as such (object as object)

HDG.FS.content: “reflection,” Latin re-flexere, turning-back upon itself (zurückzuwenden), towards the ego > in Descartes, ego, as cogitans, appears as cogitatum, object > in Kant’s language: “it must be possible for the I think to accompany all my representations” > transcendental apperception re: finite essence of man > Hegel absolutizes finite understanding, brings power of conjoining to absolute power: “what is finite w/ man becomes the infinite Absolute” > infinite as sublation of finite
HDG.FS.linkedContent: “reflection,” Latin re-flexere, turning-back upon itself (zurückzuwenden), towards the ego > in Descartes, ego, as cogitans, appears as cogitatum, object > in Kant’s language: “it must be possible for the I think to accompany all my representations” > transcendental apperception re: finite essence of man > Hegel absolutizes finite understanding, brings power of conjoining to absolute power: “what is finite w/ man becomes the infinite Absolute” > infinite as sublation of finite

HDG.FS.content: all metaphysics rests on fundamental experience of being specific to thinker: for Kant, experience of being as “Nature” > experience (the key word of CPR), for Kant, in scientific sense, mathematical physics (science par excellence since modern times) > still today, biology becomes biophysics, can predict/prepare mastery of genesis of man, anthropology becomes anthropo-physics, appearance of cybernetics
HDG.FS.linkedContent: all metaphysics rests on fundamental experience of being specific to thinker: for Kant, experience of being as “Nature” > experience (the key word of CPR), for Kant, in scientific sense, mathematical physics (science par excellence since modern times) > still today, biology becomes biophysics, can predict/prepare mastery of genesis of man, anthropology becomes anthropo-physics, appearance of cybernetics

HDG.FS.content: Kant: “I have therefore found it necessary to deny (aufheben) knowledge, in order to make room for faith” > precisely this bringing-to-its-place (an-seinen-Ort-bringen) of theoretical knowledge [this Aufhebung] allows corresponding location (entsprechende Ortschaft) of practical reason to become visible
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Kant: “I have therefore found it necessary to deny (aufheben) knowledge, in order to make room for faith” > precisely this bringing-to-its-place (an-seinen-Ort-bringen) of theoretical knowledge [this Aufhebung] allows corresponding location (entsprechende Ortschaft) of practical reason to become visible

HDG.FS.content: for Greeks, phenomenon is the thing in itself (an abyss btwn Aristotle & Kant) > unity of ta onta and ta phainomena impossible for Kant > the being has become an ob-ject (res obstans), expression “object” has no correlate in Geek
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Greeks, phenomenon is the thing in itself (an abyss btwn Aristotle & Kant) > unity of ta onta and ta phainomena impossible for Kant > the being has become an ob-ject (res obstans), expression “object” has no correlate in Geek

HDG.FS.content: Aristotle asks what’s extant (seiend) in time?—this is a reduction, a temporal predetermination is operative > for Kant, time conceived in horizon of ob-jectivity, that which holds itself steady in constant flow of changing now > Heidegger explains how short-circuiting of meditation on time covred over meaning of being > “thinking must consequently attempt to further a new—non-metaphysical—way of thinking time [overcoming metaphysics], not governed, surreptitiously, by ontological presupposition of beinghood of time, which concentrates only on what presences
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Aristotle asks what’s extant (seiend) in time?—this is a reduction, a temporal predetermination is operative > for Kant, time conceived in horizon of ob-jectivity, that which holds itself steady in constant flow of changing now > Heidegger explains how short-circuiting of meditation on time covred over meaning of being > “thinking must consequently attempt to further a new—non-metaphysical—way of thinking time [overcoming metaphysics], not governed, surreptitiously, by ontological presupposition of beinghood of time, which concentrates only on what presences

HDG.FS.content: unified question: being as position (Setzung) converges w/ totality of self-evident presuppositions & this convergence nourishes modern technological thinking > this unity evident in Kant’s title Metaphysical Foundations of Natural Science
HDG.FS.linkedContent: unified question: being as position (Setzung) converges w/ totality of self-evident presuppositions & this convergence nourishes modern technological thinking > this unity evident in Kant’s title Metaphysical Foundations of Natural Science

HDG.FS.content: Heidegger on movedness (Bewegtheit), central to Aristotle’s Physics, but not in Kant’s table of categories: Kant didn’t unfold relation of movedness to being
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Heidegger on movedness (Bewegtheit), central to Aristotle’s Physics, but not in Kant’s table of categories: Kant didn’t unfold relation of movedness to being

HDG.FS.content: technology not grounded in physics, physics grounded in essence of technology > [Kant establishes program of program] physics observes nature as succession [series, sequence] of things, not as course of things emerging (hervorgehenden) from each other [like Aristotle]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: technology not grounded in physics, physics grounded in essence of technology > [Kant establishes program of program] physics observes nature as succession [series, sequence] of things, not as course of things emerging (hervorgehenden) from each other [like Aristotle]

HDG.FS.content: Kantian “Copernican revolution”: the thing is adjusted in advance to power of knowing, category “substance” brings manifold of hyletic data into definite form, object posited as synthesis of intuition/concept > for Kant, knowledge = bringing-into-form (accomplished by understanding)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Kantian “Copernican revolution”: the thing is adjusted in advance to power of knowing, category “substance” brings manifold of hyletic data into definite form, object posited as synthesis of intuition/concept > for Kant, knowledge = bringing-into-form (accomplished by understanding)

HDG.FS.content: Husserl attempts to articulate what Kant simply characterizes as concept of form: thus the given (Gegebenen) of intuition, categorial intuition, category more than a form > categorial as given
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Husserl attempts to articulate what Kant simply characterizes as concept of form: thus the given (Gegebenen) of intuition, categorial intuition, category more than a form > categorial as given

HDG.FS.content: for Husserl, the categorial, the forms, the “is” can be encountered (whereas, for Kant, they’re just deduced from table of judgment), the fact (Tatsache) of the category can be encountered (vorfinden)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Husserl, the categorial, the forms, the “is” can be encountered (whereas, for Kant, they’re just deduced from table of judgment), the fact (Tatsache) of the category can be encountered (vorfinden)

HDG.CCP.content: thinking understood traditionally, as re-presenting, a kind of willing > like Kant, who calls thinking spontaneity: to think is to will, to will to think
HDG.CCP.linkedContent: thinking understood traditionally, as re-presenting, a kind of willing > like Kant, who calls thinking spontaneity: to think is to will, to will to think

HDG.DL.content: on the unavoidability of metaphysics, via Kant, its unbroken rule (ungebrochene Herrschaft) [mastery] establishes itself where we don’t expect it [overcoming metaphysics?]
HDG.DL.linkedContent: on the unavoidability of metaphysics, via Kant, its unbroken rule (ungebrochene Herrschaft) [mastery] establishes itself where we don’t expect it [overcoming metaphysics?]
